abstract.p: Vincent Spadea accepts invitation to play on US Olympic tennis team (S)

block.p: Vincent Spadea accepted an invitation yesterday from the United States Tennis Association to take the open singles spot on the American Olympic team vacated by Andre Agassi, the 1996 gold medalist, who withdrew for personal reasons. Spadea, who was approved by the International Tennis Federation, was still awaiting approval from Olympic officials last night.

Spadea, 26, entered the United States Open ranked No. 119 in the world, and he lost in the first round in four sets to Todd Martin. Although Spadea finished 1999 with a career-high world ranking of No. 20, that quickly plummeted when he lost 21 consecutive matches, worst on the ATP Tour.

Spadea, who was approved by the International Tennis Federation, was still awaiting approval from Olympic officials last night.

Spadea, 26, entered the United States Open ranked No. 119 in the world, and he lost in the first round in four sets to Todd Martin. Although Spadea finished 1999 with a career-high world ranking of No. 20, that quickly plummeted when he lost 21 consecutive matches, worst on the ATP Tour.
The streak began at the end of last year and continued until the first round of Wimbledon, when he defeated Greg Rusedski, a finalist in the 1997 United States Open.
His one experience playing for the United States also ended in a loss when he played one match in the Davis Cup against Spain this summer, losing to Juan Carlos Ferrero, 4-6, 6-1, 6-4.
